title: folios on resume
content:
:)

Would you even have folios?

Well, I would like them not for ordering but to hold it together. For example Page 1/3, Page 2/3, Page 3/3. It just makes me feel safer because an incomplete copy is clearly marked as incomplete.

The audience are recruiters who rush through resumes are an alarming pace. From what I can gather, their eyes track the page top-left to bottom-right and if they get distracted or did not see what they are looking for, its in the bin.

However, with such a short collection of pages, some folio positions just do not work. For example, if you bleed the right hand edge then Page 3/3 causes them to look for Page 4/3 and they get confused (witnessed it first hand). While that is not an immediate problem for most jobs, its clearly flawed and may reflect badly if applying for design-related jobs - so its in the bin.

So where should they go? :)
author: stormbind

comments.content:
It sounds like you have a much bigger problem with your design/hierarchy, something that folio placement isn't going to solve.

Also, a three page resume is probably two pages too long, especially if it's going to people who are just skimming them. Edit it down to something short and digestible.

If youâ€™re applying for the kind of jobs that are filled by people who are quickly skimming resumes you should probably edit down to one page and save the longer version for the few people who will actually sit down and read it.

Thing is, I do not know who is going to read it. Those awful personnel departments tend to sift through resumes before giving a list to recruiters.

Sometimes they OCR the document and use computers to scan for keywords. That's a problem that my thread is not addressing :)

Hi Jackson, could you please elaborate? I will confess to having too much to put in my resume. My last career advisor was really stuck and told me to take out education because it was the weakest part (I am postgraduate).

<cite>- The audience are recruiters who rush through resumes are an alarming pace. From what I can gather, their eyes track the page top-left to bottom-right and if they get distracted or did not see what they are looking for, its in the bin.</cite>

If people aren't taking the time to read everything on your resume, the solution isn't going to be adding more information (folios). You need to edit down (a lot) and make the information skim-able (by adjusting your typographic hierarchy).

<cite>- I will confess to having too much to put in my resume.</cite>

There you go.

Point taken, thanks :)

I'm not sure its easy in practice because statements must be substantiated with qualified examples.
